channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15513] hbase.hregion.memstore.chunkpool.maxsize is 0.0 by default
item.description: That results in excessive MemStoreLAB chunk allocations because we can not reuse them. Not sure, why it has been disabled, by default. May be the code has not been tested well?

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Server-side.
See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-8163 It was intentionally off by default.
I should have added, I wonder what happens when you enable it?

Stack

I should have added, I wonder what happens when you enable it?

Good improvements in Old and Young GC times. It reduced Old GC events by 50% and time by 60%. See parent ticket. This MUST be enabled by default, I think.

The problem with disabling this pool - all new chunks (2MB each) are allocated in tenured space. Because we do not reuse them, only Old Gen GC will clean the space and Old GC can be very expensive sometimes. It affects Young GC as well.

There was another Jira raised some time back to remove the MSLAB pool !!! I forgot the issue id.
Ya I also feel it is useful.. Specially we plan to have an off heap memstore impl. Here the cell data will be in offheap and we think that we can have an Offheap MSLAB pool in place. We must be pooling off heap space if MSLAB impl is off heap
Rereading the issue, it is not a clear win in all situations (unfortunately). We need to test and with G1GC.

There was, yes. What was it?

So, this issue should be about doing a bit of testing of at least YCSB loadings to see that enabling the pool is beneficial all around?

So, this issue should be about doing a bit of testing of at least YCSB loadings to see that enabling the pool is beneficial all around?

Stack Can you explain how not reusing buffers can improve performance and latency? I am just trying to understand magic physics of "allocate buffer on every request" approach.

Stack Can you explain how not reusing buffers can improve performance and latency? I am just trying to understand magic physics of "allocate buffer on every request" approach.

See where Elliott wanted a flag to disable pooled bytebuffers because it put a spanner in his G1GC works; HBASE-14942. On the face of it 'reuse' should be always better but the Elliott issue and a new one coming in that ramkrishna.s.vasudevan and Anoop Sam John are studying a case where resuse seems to make for less GC but the GC runs for longer, would seem to indicate that 'reuse' is not panacea. My suggestion is we do some basic testing to verify no side effects..... Do it now as part of check-in rather than let some poor sod down the line figure there an unexpected regression (and have to figure it without context). See the original issue too where there is discussion on when to enable the pool.
Did initial some tests with G1GC. But let me come back to this after completing the full analysis.
Maybe you thinking of slabcache Anoop Sam John HBASE-11307 ?
No there was a Jira to remove the MSLAB chunk pool fully.. I think it was by Lars H.
Oh yeah, HBASE-14613 A bunch of work done over there. Yeah, Lars wants to remove it and was trying to gather evidence that enabling improved our GC profile.

Over in HBASE-14613 I was having trouble finding the cutoff at which allocations happened in old gen.

A comment that suggests turning off MSLAB altogther when running on G1GC is worth digging in more on: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-15180?focusedCommentId=15124036&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15124036

Not an expert in G1GC, but the with old CMS sometimes, under heavy pressure, not only large objects, but a small are prematurely promoted to Tenured space. Every chunk of MemSLAB (2MB) will eventually get into tenured space in CMS and then will be discarded on MemStore flush. That is why we need to reuse them, otherwise we just accumulate garbage in tenured space.

MemSLAB chunk pool must be enabled, at least in CMS. There are some debates whether it should be enabled in G1GC or not.

Recommendation:
Set hbase.hregion.memstore.chunkpool.maxsize to memstore default size (0.4f)

Set hbase.hregion.memstore.chunkpool.maxsize to memstore default size (0.4f)

hbase.hregion.memstore.chunkpool.maxsize is not the % heap memory to be used for chunk pool. By this we need to say % of memstore memory to be used for the pool.
So if we say this as 0.4 , then the total max heap size which the pool can use is
xmx value * 0.4 (def memstore size) * 0.4

So if we want whole of the memstore to be memstore chunk pool, give this a value 1

FYI.
Reopen. You make a good point. Let's do the work to figure if this should be always on

According to this comment

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-15180?focusedCommentId=15126122&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15126122

MSLAB with chunk pool on is the best performer even with G1GC.
Anoop Sam John As the memstore size changes, the chunkpool will change along with it? Or will it just get fixed at whatever the original memstore size was?

-1 overall

This message was automatically generated.

It is like fixed at the init time. Say we have 10GB max heap size and 40% as memstore size (ie. 4GB) and if hbase.hregion.memstore.chunkpool.maxsize = 1, then 4 GB is reserved for MSLAB pool. So it is not changing with memstore size.
Ya when the auto tuner changes the memstore size (up or down), this chunk size wont get changed too.. May be that is some thing wrong and to be corrected?

Yes.

Autotuner should be on by default if it is not... in 1.3?
Good point. Yes we may need this feature.

Looking for guidance on this as well. We are still running CMS due to the fact that we could not get G1GC latency under ~100ms (max). So is the advice to set 


hbase.hregion.memstore.chunkpool.initialsize = 1

hbase.hregion.memstore.chunkpool.maxsize = 1

Then disable heap autotuning chore?

Jeremy Carroll

Yes, those are right settings. Auto-tuning should be disabled as well (for now). Thanks for reviving this ticket.
Anoop Sam John so we need to adjust chunk pool size to new values of a heap tuner automatically?

Vladimir Rodionov
The chunk pool size adjustment has been in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-16407.

-1 overall

This message was automatically generated.
Is chunk pool still disabled by default, after HBASE-16407? Do I have to close this ticket?

HBASE-16407 is doing the auto adjustment of chunk pool size if it is enabled. I have not changed it to be enabled by default. So yes still the chunk pool is disable. So this ticket is still valid.

hbase.hregion.memstore.chunkpool.initialsize = 1
hbase.hregion.memstore.chunkpool.maxsize = 1

The initial size might not be required to be 100% IMO. May be go with 50%? (0.5).

These are test results with G1GC:

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-15180?focusedCommentId=15126122&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15126122

We have many confirmations, that chunk pool has a value and default size should be increased from 0 to 1.0.
Stack, ramkrishna vasudevan, Anoop Sam John if you have any doubts, questions, objections - its time to raise your hand .

Ya at least the tests what we did using CMS and G1 shows that chunk pool still have value. With G1GC and with out chunk pool, we were able to get latency and GC pause same as with pool case BUT with much more heap size allocated for the RS. So said that, the chunk pool was helping us to achieve what we wanted with lower heap size. Also to mention that here we set global memstore upper limit as 43% only as we wanted to keep the IHOP for G1GC as some thing like 50% max.
Anoop Sam John, how about +1?

The reason why chunk pool is better with G1GC is as Anoop stated but that is for lower heap sizes. For higher heap sizes may be it is not needed to be ON by default? So am not very sure whether we should always enable this chunkpool. When we use offheap MSLAB then yes, it has to be ON, so that we avoid offheap memory fragmentation.
What tests are you pointing at Vladimir Rodionov? The above link just drops me into the middle of the issue. Are we talking new set of tests or just regurgitating old knowledge? Thanks.

Ya at least the tests what we did using CMS and G1 shows that chunk pool still have value. With G1GC and with out chunk pool, we were able to get latency and GC pause same as with pool case BUT with much more heap size allocated for the RS. So said that, the chunk pool was helping us to achieve what we wanted with lower heap size. Also to mention that here we set global memstore upper limit as 43% only as we wanted to keep the IHOP for G1GC as some thing like 50% max.

I have run my own as well and measured memory allocation rate (not latency) and major GC frequency.

Good improvements in Old and Young GC times. It reduced Old GC events by 50% and time by 60%.

The reason why chunk pool is better with G1GC is as Anoop stated but that is for lower heap sizes. For higher heap sizes may be it is not needed to be ON by default? So am not very sure whether we should always enable this chunkpool. When we use offheap MSLAB then yes, it has to be ON, so that we avoid offheap memory fragmentation.
Pool can also hamper performance as all cores have to coordinate around add and remove to the pool.

ramkrishna.s.vasudevan and Anoop Sam John These are the offheap write tests you did? Want to add a pointer here?

I have run my own as well and measured memory allocation rate (not latency) and major GC frequency.

What kind of test was it Vladimir Rodionov You don't provide data or detail on the test setup.

Offheap write path needs chunkpool on. Fellas who have run the G1GC in production, want pooling off because it makes their run profile worse.

What kind of test was it

I load 1B small rows (rowkey=16 byte, value = 8 bytes) using BufferedMutator with batch size 1000. Table has 1 CF, only one region, splits are disabled. Compaction is on, but maximum selection size is limited to 1GB. Test runs locally on my laptop (MBP, fast SSD).

HBASE-15561 has some nice numbers in favor of pool and MSLAB (G1GC)

We have gotten already enough evidence in support for turing chunk pool on, by default.

I think we have no objections to make this feature on, by default (see discussion in HBASE-15561).

Let us commit it. Ted Yu, Enis Soztutar, ramkrishna vasudevan?
+1 to commit.
Do we need 100% of the max global heap space size as def pool size? I feel it can be lesser.
100% guarantees that we won't be reallocating buffers too often (may be never), anything less than 100% won't gives us such a guarantee. That is going to be partial chunk pool.
I think this easy to reason about.

Ok on making def max pool space as 100% as per the explanation. This is any way max size. Am +1 on patch now.
Stack, ramkrishna.s.vasudevan
Stack, ramkrishna vasudevan?
We have two +1. One more, Stack?
Committed to master. Thanks for the patch Vladimir Rodionov Lets see how we do.

There is a jira to default ON the heap memory tuning also. That should be also committed now as that will give chance to release some of the buffers we keep in the ChukPool if at present there are not much write reqs and release memstore memory area is ok.
Do we need to mark this as incompatible change as there is a behave change now wrt handling of RS memory?
Test failure because in TestMemStoreLAB is because of this commit. Will attach simple addendum to fix it.

Unable to commit as git pull is failing for me
error: Ref refs/remotes/origin/HBASE-14850 is at 57422675d0280ef10b7c1f588bbaf69ddfd0935d but expected 6cadc3828b714c31380df8f274c9a7fd6916a475
From https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/hbase
! 6cadc38..0bb115b HBASE-14850 -> origin/HBASE-14850 (unable to update local ref)

FAILURE: Integrated in Jenkins build HBase-Trunk_matrix #1931 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-Trunk_matrix/1931/)
HBASE-15513 hbase.hregion.memstore.chunkpool.maxsize is 0.0 by default (stack: rev 8b4bb34ec29317da0d7c75c8bb6af89f420d880c)

  • (edit) hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/regionserver/MemStoreChunkPool.java

Thanks for reopening Anoop Sam John I showed up here to reopen. I reverted the change because TestMemStoreLAB is failing for me. Whats the addendum?

For the git pull failing, try the git gc. For some reason that 'fixes' the issue, but why I'm not sure (git experts?)
Is it the issue you reported with branch names Anoop Sam John?

I have attached an addendum patch here. Small change.
Ya seems that is the issue. We have branches named hbase-14850 and HBASE-14850. Need to remove the duplicated one. In linux box it is ok. In windows the duplicated branch name make things ambiguous.
So our git gc clears out the old branch? Good one. Let me reapply w/ your addendum Anoop Sam John Thanks.

Pushed again with addendum by Anoop Sam John

Marked it as incompatible change.
What is the issue Anoop Sam John? Thanks.

I mean , now we make MSLAB pool ON by default and 100% memstore size is the max size. So if there are writes we will keep adding MSLAB chunks to pool. This will be permanent in the pool. Later when there are not many writes also we will occupy 40% of the memory with SLAB chunks (def value am taking).. The Heap tuner, if ON, will tune the memstore size down and that will even do release of some of the unwanted chunks. THat is why I was saying we need to turn heap tuner also ON by def now. There is a jira for that already. Make sense?
It does. What is the JIRA number? Thanks.
HBASE-16401

SUCCESS: Integrated in Jenkins build HBase-Trunk_matrix #1934 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-Trunk_matrix/1934/)
